info.game_comments:
2016 Teen Tournament quarterfinal game 1.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: The name of this British monetary unit comes from a unit of weight

(2, 1).clue: By any measure this object is 36 inches long

(3, 1).clue: He's the title lion in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe", the first Narnia book

(4, 1).clue: Beyonce has more than 60 million followers on this photo-sharing app whose logo looks like a Polaroid camera

(5, 1).clue: Oxford says this preposition is the 7th-most common word in English; it's in this clue twice

(1, 2).clue: From 1792 to 1873 the U.S. issued silver 5-cent coins called not nickels but "half" these

(2, 2).clue: This symbol seen right before our name

(3, 2).clue: Miraz, the king of Narnia, is the uncle of this title royal of the second book in the series

(4, 2).clue: Twenty One Pilots "wish we could turn back time to the good old days... but now we're" this title

(5, 2).clue: Because of metal shortages, from 1943 to 1945 these famous award statuettes were made of plaster

(1, 3).clue: The Lincoln Memorial is on the back of this U.S. bill

(2, 3).clue: This word is a synonym for versus

(3, 3).clue: In the fifth book of the chronicles, Bree, a talking one of these, & a boy named Shasta ride to Narnia--& freedom

(4, 3).clue: Creepers love the gaming channel stampylonghead & its devotion to this ubiquitous Mojang game

(5, 3).clue: The traditional "Big 3" of U.S. automakers are Chrysler, General Motors & this one

(1, 4).clue: A silver tetradrachm from the 300s B.C. features a great portrait of him

(2, 4).clue: It's a belief, not based in reason, that something bad will happen if you perform a particular action... or if you don't

(3, 4).clue: Digory is the title relative of this sixth book that also features his "enchanting" uncle Andrew

(4, 4).clue: In 2016 this member of One Direction became a dad to a lad named Freddie

(5, 4).clue: This state's richest man is French fry tycoon Scott Simplot

(1, 5).clue: English settlers in the New World used this word from Algonquian for beads used as Indian money

(2, 5).clue: One definition is a stitched-together type of publication having between 5 & 48 pages

(3, 5).clue: "Farewell to Shadowlands" is the last chapter of this seventh & "Last" book in the chronicles

(4, 5).clue: Avicii, a 26-year-old superstar in EDM, this type of music, has announced he is retiring

(5, 5).clue: This alloy of copper & tin gave its name to a cultural "Age"

(1, 1).clue: My favorite part of going is watching the previews called these, like something a car pulls

(2, 1).clue: This Austrian monk found pairs of genes separate in a random fashion when a plant's gametes form

(3, 1).clue: A hole in a boat, or information given to the press without permission

(4, 1).clue: A land bridge called al Lisan separates this "corpselike" body of water into a Southern Basin & a Northern Basin

(5, 1).clue: Teen emperor Elagabalus forced all important Romans to worship Elah-gabal, a sun type of this

(6, 1).clue: This number is represented by the Roman numeral X

(1, 2).clue: I love this format that gives "up to 40% more image" & "highest quality 3D"

(2, 2).clue: Surely this rings a bell: the name of this physiologist who studied the secretory activity of digestion from 1890 to 1900

(3, 2).clue: It's a "g"ift from the "g"overnment to an organization; block is one type

(4, 2).clue: This ocean's greatest depth, about 18,000 feet, lies at around 82 degrees north latitude

(5, 2).clue: This Shoshone teen was an asset in many ways for Lewis & Clark, including finding edible plants during the journey

(6, 2).clue: In a letter or message, an X symbolizes one of these

(1, 3).clue: The ticket guy knows me, so I'm front row center for this 2016 monster movie sequel with an address for a title

(2, 3).clue: This Swede's original scale had water's boiling point at 0 degrees & its freezing point at 100

(3, 3).clue: An envoy such as an ambassador; it can also mean anyone who's tactful & avoids outright conflict

(4, 3).clue: This second-longest African river takes its name from a kingdom that once existed near its mouth

(5, 3).clue: In 2016 a British 15-year-old got $250,000 for winning a new race of these remote-controlled craft around a track

(6, 3).clue: This male first name starting with "X" is also a Jesuit university in Cincinnati

(1, 4).clue: I scream, you scream for these bite-sized chocolate-covered ice cream treats with a double talk name

(2, 4).clue: This giant of modern physics was diagnosed with ALS as a graduate student at Cambridge

(3, 4).clue: Though they weren't mounting pictures, the Founding Fathers who wrote the Constitution are known as this

(4, 4).clue: The Gulf of Mannar between India & this island nation is noted for its pearl banks & the sacred chank, a gastropod mollusk

(5, 4).clue: He was just 18 when he joined brother Frank & the Younger Gang to rob his first bank in 1866

(6, 4).clue: In the 1637 work "Geometrie" he introduced the use of X, Y & Z as symbols of unknown quantities

(1, 5).clue: Before we go, we should check out the ratings on this website that sounds like something you throw at a bad film

(2, 5).clue: This Rome-born physicist designed the first nuclear reactor

(3, 5).clue: Once there were hopes for an overall budget agreement between Obama & the GOP, the "grand" this type of deal

(4, 5).clue: The Strait of Tiquina connects the northern & southern parts of this lake in the Andes

(5, 5).clue: As a teen, this "Birds of America" artist conducted the first bird-banding on the continent by using thread

(6, 5).clue: X Division at this New Mexico national lab is the USA's center for the physics of nuclear weapons

(0, 0).clue: It was constructed in the Paris foundry of Gaget, Gauthier & Co. from 1875 to 1884
